author: 831sweatyfeet
body:
This is a well argued bear thesis. I guess as much as anything, we should be looking beyond what happens next month as you suggest. 

Even if it's not a V shaped recovery, it doesn't make it a market that you shouldn't invest into. 

It just means you need to adjust your expectations and further your timeline. This market is rewarding companies that have navigated well not just throughout the Corona Virus, but have also stood the test of time. 

Apple and Microsoft both faced challenging times in their histories, but they made it through. 

We've also been fully trained to be forward looking. That's why you have NKLA, TSLA, ZM, DKNG, LULU, DOCU, ADBE, NVDA all trading at crazy valuations. People are willing to gamble on the long term success of what they see as great companies.

I think if you look at everything that has happened recently, we've all shrugged the effects of Covid-19 off, regardless of the consequences. 

We're not slowing down the American economy anymore at this point. It took a heinous act for us to get off the couch and hit the streets, but it felt good to be back around other people again. I feel like so many people are in a different state of mind than a few months ago.

author: Cam2071
body:
They burned me before. Sell before the earnings call. 

You'll get killed by the volatility. 

I remember in September I played their earnings and bought $6k in calls. The day of the earnings call my $6k had turned to $10k. I should have sold EOD and locked that shit in. But I wanted to LET IT RIDE like a true autist. And I got burned, they beat everything and lowered future guidance. Apparently ADBE has a habit of doing this, they under promise  so they can consistently beat earnings. Anyways the stock dipped the next morning and I got killed by volatility barely cashed out with $5k

author: notbrokemexican
body:
Thank you so much for this engagement.

I have to get back to work but I would like to write a few notes to get back to. I really appreciate it.

- software automation and AR tech will augment core products like MSFT and APPLE. Automated drawing on iPads? Yes. Software automations on O365 and Windows machines? Yes please. I think those acquisitions highlight their approach.

Apple and their relationship with Adobe is the biggest contender to FB. FBs reach is enormous but that may change with iPhone price decline in places like Mexico where Huawei has aggressively ran their footing.

- brkshire vs Costco; comparison was supposed to highlight their MO of finding excellent quality (excellent value or product)

- I view cloud computing as an distributor ML. Google's ML kit for example. Both are operators of massive data dams and rivers.

author: 1monster90
body:
You shouldn't invest money you can't afford to lose. Personally, money in the stock market is money I am considering nonexistent until 2045.   
Don't be greedy but don't be cynical either. I think you could really benefit from making a list of interesting stocks. And from that list try to pick at least 10 stocks that you find promising and buy. Even if it's just 1 share (that way you will be focused on these companies, it's not so much to make a profit than making yourself focus and research these companies. I find it easier to focus on stocks I have at least one share with that stocks I don't own at all).  


Here is my list of shares I'm watching carefully, feel free to research it.  
MSFT, V, MA, NKE, NTDOY, LOGI, SPXL, TQQQ, DOCU,  TRIP, ALGN, F, GME, APPL, NFLX, SBUX, LUV, HS, AMZN, AAL, TMUS, PG,  INTC, QCOM, PYPL, T, ATVI, RSG, FDM, AXP, CSCO, TGT, PLSE, TROW, ORCL,  FDX, CUBE, BABA, CTAS, ALK, JNJ, LLY, CB, NEE, FANG, GAMR, TWLO, TNA,  LABU, FAS, CTRE, PEP, EBAY, DFS, GE, SNQP, MS, RF, AMG, HIG, BR, BEN,  ZNGA, COR, WWE, WYNN, VT, VTI, ELY, ADBE, SQ, TWTR, CVS, CRSP, QQ, NDLS,  WU, MTRX, PUTW, TECL, GM, NYMT, MU and NDAQ .

You should buy some. If it drops, then buy more. I think this stock will be a $7,000 stock someday and will hit $1200 in the next 12 months and possibly even by the end of the year.

It’s vulnerable to more volatility short term but if you’re playing the long game, it’s hard to go wrong.

Buy some and keep some cash available in case you get a good deal. Shopify is a runaway winner for small business owners. I’ve been a web developer for the last decade and the competition is decent but not great. Shopify is the clear de facto solution just like Salesforce, Adobe, etc.

They bought Magento, an ecommerce platform. They also have some exposure to AI (Adobe Sensei) and automation.

I didn't know about their educational software but they increase their software product offerings pretty regularly, so that's another good example.

Overall they have a very lucrative and very captive core business that they use as a base to expand into other segments (bought Magento for 1.6 billion).

One of my top 5 positions and I don't see selling anytime soon. Just added more last month.

author: cfreak2399
body:
This is just wrong. For one thing, Adobe and Microsoft both already have versions of their software for the iPad Pro. Moving to Macs with the same chip isn't requiring a rewrite. It's requiring a recompile of existing code and a few fixes. They said in the announcement they are already working with both.  Apple didn't become the giant company they are by being stupid.  

The interfaces are the same so for almost any other developer writing software for the Mac is going to be a similar proposition. Recompile, fix a bug or two. 

Chip architecture is vastly abstracted away, even more now than it was 20 years ago when Apple went to Intel in the first place. Most software developers are writing in Javascript which can target web, mobile, and desktop (electron). Anyone writing native apps specifically for Mac will notice almost no difference because Apple will provide all the tools.  Anyone writing apps for something else is using Windows in the first place or if they are using a Mac they're compiling using virtualization which is going to work exactly the same way.

Very few developers care about x86 vs anything else and any who do are probably already using Windows.

author: shuttdown700
body:
MSFT is just under 20% of my portfolio (it’s one of my equity hedges against another dive). MSFT is a solid buy and forget company. 100% into it though is never really a good idea (and I know you don’t feel like you have a lot of capital to diversify). I have two 20% hedge equity holdings (one being MSFT and the other AMZN) and I’ve missed some good broad market movement cause I decreased my broad exposure. Still doing great, but I’d be really disappointed in the short term if I hadn’t diversified into my lesser holdings.

If I were you I’d pick ~4 solid companies to split the funds with. Ideas = AMZN (fractional shares), FB, BRK, V, MA, DG, COST, ADBE (earnings next week)...etc

body:
Amazon, Shopify, AMD, Microsoft, Adobe, DocuSign

#1 rule is buy things that will grow and keep growing significantly. I like industry dominance and a long runway for future growth. I don’t buy companies where I can’t see a long 5-10 year pathway for growth. I may buy a few for an 18-36 month timeframe but most of holdings are stocks I plan to never sell
